Bloomberg.heading: Alphabet Earnings Need to Justify Its Stocks $2 Trillion Rally
Bloomberg.summary:
Alphabet Inc. is currently regarded as a leader across key sectors of the artificial intelligence (AI) industry, supported by a highly regarded AI model, advanced semiconductors, a rapidly growing cloud-computing business, and a dominant position in digital advertising. This has driven Alphabet’s share price to an all-time high and brought its market capitalization to $4.1 trillion, within 5% of Nvidia’s $4.4 trillion valuation. Alphabet's valuation is at its highest in 18 years, with shares trading at about 28 times estimated earnings, above the 10-year average of 21.

The company’s latest AI developments, including the release of its Gemini AI model and its tensor processing unit chips used in Google Cloud, have reassured investors of Alphabet’s innovation leadership. Its cloud segment is anticipated to experience strong growth in the coming years, potentially boosting free cash flow. The YouTube platform remains a leading streaming service, and its autonomous driving unit Waymo recently raised $16 billion at a $126 billion valuation, nearly tripling its October 2024 valuation.

Ahead of the earnings report, analysts expect Alphabet to report revenue growth around 17% and earnings per share growth of 23%. However, concerns remain about whether this growth justifies the company’s high valuation, particularly with a projected 28% rise in capital expenditures to $117 billion in 2026. Investor confidence hinges on sustained growth and returns from recent AI investments, especially as comparable tech firms like Microsoft face scrutiny over AI spending.

Alphabet’s performance contrasts with recent market turmoil triggered by AI developments, such as a $285 billion selloff linked to a new AI tool from Anthropic PBC, which affected multiple sectors. Despite some short-term stock volatility, Alphabet’s broad range of growth drivers and strategic AI initiatives position it for potential continued expansion.

Bloomberg.heading: Alphabet Plans Record Spending in Race to Dominate AI Market
Bloomberg.summary:
Alphabet Inc. plans to spend up to $185 billion on capital expenditures in 2026, surpassing its combined investment of the past three years and doubling its 2025 spending. This increase supports an extensive expansion of data centers aimed at advancing its artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities. The company reported fourth-quarter revenues of $97.23 billion, exceeding expectations, driven by strong performance in its cloud and search advertising businesses.

CEO Sundar Pichai emphasized that the heavy investment is essential for sustaining growth and competing with rivals such as Amazon, Microsoft, and OpenAI. Approximately 40% of technical infrastructure investments are allocated to data centers and networking equipment, with the remaining 60% focused on servers. Alphabet expects constraints related to power and supply chains as it scales up.

The company’s AI model Gemini is integrated across multiple products, including the Chrome browser, and reached 750 million active users by December, up from 650 million three months prior. The cloud business backlog more than doubled year-over-year to $240 billion, reflecting strong demand for AI-driven enterprise services. Gemini Enterprise gained over 8 million paid users since its launch four months ago.

Alphabet also supplies AI chips to Anthropic and provides AI technology for Apple’s Siri. AI agents reportedly write about 50% of Alphabet’s own code. Google Cloud revenue rose 48% year-over-year to $17.7 billion, surpassing expectations.

The company’s Other Bets division, which includes Waymo, posted $370 million in Q4 revenue with a $3.6 billion operating loss, wider than analysts anticipated. Alphabet participated significantly in Waymo’s $16 billion funding round, valuing the autonomous vehicle unit at $126 billion. Research and development expenses increased 42%, driven mainly by AI talent costs and support for Waymo.

YouTube maintained growth, with its Shorts format averaging 200 billion daily views, and total YouTube ad and subscription revenue exceeded $60 billion in 2025. Despite these positive results, Alphabet’s shares dropped 3.2% following the announcements.

Bloomberg.heading: Amazon Cloud Sales in Focus After Microsofts $500 Billion Rout
Bloomberg.summary:
Amazon.com Inc. is set to report its earnings on Thursday amid heightened scrutiny of its cloud business, following a significant share price decline at Microsoft Corp., which cited slowing growth in its Azure cloud platform. Amazon's shares had previously risen nearly 10% after stronger-than-expected revenue from its cloud unit, Amazon Web Services (AWS), but concerns about a broader slowdown in the cloud sector have resurfaced, affecting investor sentiment. Microsoft shares have fallen over 16% since late January, wiping out about $500 billion in market value.

Wall Street anticipates that Amazon will report a 21% year-over-year increase in AWS revenue to $34.8 billion for the fourth quarter. Overall company revenue is expected to rise 13% to $211.5 billion, with adjusted earnings per share projected at $2.40, up 8% year-over-year. Amazon's stock performance has lagged behind major indices, gaining just 5.2% in 2025 and less than 1% in 2026 to date, compared to the Nasdaq 100’s 20% and the S&P 500’s 16% increases in 2025.

Alphabet Inc. also reported strong cloud growth recently but saw its shares dip following announcements of higher-than-expected capital expenditures for 2026. Microsoft was downgraded by Stifel due to concerns about Azure’s growth trajectory. The tech sector faces pressure amid heavy AI-related investments, creating uncertainty about the timing of returns on these expenditures.

Amazon's shares trade at about 23 times forward earnings, below its 10-year average of 46 and slightly below the Nasdaq 100 average of 24. Investors are focused on whether Amazon can deliver the high growth rates now expected by the market. Beyond AWS performance, analysts will watch for Amazon’s margin trends, retail business strength, developments related to its AI initiatives including the Rufus chatbot, and capital spending plans.

Amazon invested $8 billion in AI firm Anthropic in November 2024, which contributed to a 38% profit increase in the previous quarter, including a $9.5 billion pretax gain from this investment. Anthropic is reportedly seeking to raise $10 billion in funding at a $350 billion valuation. A potential $50 billion investment in OpenAI is also under investor scrutiny.

While Amazon has diversified revenue streams, AWS remains central to investor focus as the company’s key growth driver. Market participants expect a clear outlook on AWS amid ongoing clouds sector volatility, with options data signaling the stock could move more than 8% following the report.

Bloomberg.heading: Amazon Launches AI-Enhanced Alexa for Prime Subscribers in US
Bloomberg.summary: Amazon.com Inc. has launched an upgraded version of its AI-enhanced digital assistant, Alexa+, in the US. The new Alexa, which uses large language models to generate dynamic responses, was initially available exclusively to Amazon Prime subscribers during an 11-month early access period. Tens of millions of Prime members have used Alexa+ so far. Now, Amazon is offering a free version of Alexa+ accessible via the web and smartphone apps, featuring usage limits. Non-Prime users can subscribe to the paid version of Alexa+ for $19.99 per month, which is approximately $100 more annually than the $139 Prime membership fee. This launch intensifies competition with other AI chatbot developers, including OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, and Microsoft. Amazon is also testing Alexa+ in European countries and Canada, with plans for broader global expansion later in 2024. The company last reported 200 million Prime members in 2021.

Bloomberg.heading: Amazon Told to Stop Policing Prices, Pay $70 Million in Germany
Bloomberg.summary:
Germany’s Federal Cartel Office ordered Amazon.com Inc. to stop enforcing price controls on retailers in its German marketplace and seized €59 million ($70 million), representing estimated profits from this practice. According to the regulator, Amazon’s policy of removing or not featuring products if their prices are deemed too high violates digital economy and fair competition rules. Such measures are only permitted under exceptional circumstances, like price gouging, and must follow specific regulatory guidelines.

The Cartel Office emphasized that Amazon competes directly with other retailers on its platform, creating a risk that Amazon could control overall price levels to disadvantage other online sellers, potentially forcing them out of the market. The agency criticized Amazon’s undisclosed methods for setting these price controls and argued that the company could use alternative approaches to ensure competitive pricing.

Amazon, which accounts for about 60% of online retail sales in Germany, said it will appeal the ruling and continue operations without disruption. The company’s Germany country manager stated that Amazon has fair pricing guidelines allowing retailers to set prices independently and claimed the ruling misunderstands competitive retail dynamics, possibly harming innovation and the EU single market.

This is the first use by Germany’s antitrust watchdog of a newly granted power, enacted in 2023, to seize profits obtained through misconduct by tech companies. The regulator indicated it may seize additional funds if violations persist.

Bloomberg.heading: Australia Blasts Big Tech for Child Sexual Abuse Failings
Bloomberg.summary:
Australia’s online safety regulator, the eSafety Commissioner, criticized major technology companies, including Meta Platforms Inc., Apple Inc., and Google, for failing to effectively combat child sexual exploitation and abuse on their platforms. The regulator highlighted several issues, such as inadequate detection of live abuse during video calls and insufficient efforts to identify newly created exploitative material. A particular concern was the lack of language analysis tools necessary to detect sexual extortion targeting Australian children, despite having provided companies with common indicators to assist in this effort.

Julie Inman Grant, the eSafety Commissioner, expressed frustration over the slow progress, stating that engagement with these companies on the issue has been ongoing for a long time with little improvement. While Apple, Microsoft, and Google did not comment on the allegations, Snap Inc., owner of Snapchat, affirmed its commitment to working with the regulator but did not directly address the criticisms. Meta, which owns Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp, indicated it would review the feedback from the eSafety office.

The article also noted that global watchdogs are increasingly pressuring large tech companies to take responsibility for abuse occurring on their platforms. Adding to regulatory measures, Australia introduced a law late last year banning social media use for children under 16, making it a world-first move targeting youth online safety.

Bloomberg.heading: BofA Reworks Credit Cards to Fuel Ambitious Consumer Profit Plan
Bloomberg.summary:
Bank of America Corp. is implementing a strategy to double its consumer unit's profit to $20 billion annually by 2030, a milestone rarely achieved in the U.S. banking sector. Key elements include revamping credit card rewards, particularly by offering new incentives for customers with higher account balances, and leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to attract new and deepen relationships with existing customers. The bank aims to increase its consumer base from 69 million to 75 million over the decade.

The strategy involves expanding the customer base, using technology to better analyze data for targeted outreach, and reducing costs. Bank of America, which shifted away from riskier loans post-2008, maintains its lending standards but now employs AI to underwrite more loans, including to those with limited credit history. AI is also being applied in mortgage processing to boost underwriting capacity in anticipation of potential increases in homebuying if borrowing costs fall.

Bank of America plans to better utilize existing co-brand partnerships (e.g., Alaska Air, Royal Caribbean), enhance its no-fee, cash-back credit cards, and increase marketing spend and incentives, like doubling cash-back rates for new cardholders’ first year. Despite fluctuating customer satisfaction rankings over five years—generally trailing American Express—executives see room to improve product appeal and deepen client engagement.

Physical locations are also evolving, with the bank closing some branches while opening or renovating others in high-growth areas, and transforming branches into more modern, customer-friendly spaces staffed by bankers who assist with a range of financial services. Approximately 55,000 employees currently work in branches, but this number is expected to decline gradually as AI tools, including the bank’s “Erica” virtual assistant, enhance staff efficiency and reduce hiring needs.

Overall, Bank of America is betting on AI and data analytics to improve underwriting, risk assessment, marketing, customer experience, and operational efficiency in pursuit of its ambitious profitability goal. However, external analysts note uncertainty remains regarding the scale of benefits technology investments will deliver.

Bloomberg.heading: Berkshire Utility Presses Wildfire Appeal With Billions at Stake
Bloomberg.summary:
Berkshire Hathaway’s PacifiCorp is appealing a 2023 jury verdict in a wildfire class-action lawsuit that risks billions in losses. The utility, the largest grid operator in the western US, was found grossly negligent for failing to de-energize power lines before extreme weather sparked wildfires in Oregon in September 2020. The jury awarded $645 million to 119 victims, with potential total damages possibly exceeding $6 billion. The verdict has negatively impacted PacifiCorp’s credit rating and led the company to warn it might cease operations in Oregon.

PacifiCorp’s appeal, to be argued before the Oregon Court of Appeals, challenges the class-action status, contending that the plaintiffs, property owners affected by different fires over widespread areas, should not have been grouped together. The company also claims an Oregon law prohibits recovery of non-economic damages, disputing awards averaging $4 million per victim for emotional distress. Plaintiffs argue the trial judge correctly allowed the class action and the awards are lawful.

Approximately 1,400 additional fire victims remain to have claims resolved under an accelerated schedule in the next one to two years. The appeals court decision is expected within six months to a year.

Bloomberg.heading: Goldman Readies $3.75 Billion Debt Offering for DuPont Unit Deal
Bloomberg.summary:
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is preparing a revised $3.75 billion financing package, likely including a junk bond offering, to support Arclin Inc.’s acquisition of DuPont de Nemours Inc.’s Aramids business. The deal would consist of approximately $2.25 billion in dollar- and euro-denominated leveraged loans, $1 billion in privately-placed junk bonds, and a $500 million revolving credit facility. Discussions with investors may lead to a transaction launch as early as this week.

Previously, Goldman considered a $3 billion term loan, a $500 million revolver, and a $250 million delayed-draw loan for the deal. The revised financing follows Arclin’s recent acquisition of Willamette Valley Co. and additional equity injection from its private equity owner, TJC LP. Negotiations on the debt terms, which will also refinance Arclin’s existing term loans, are ongoing.

The adjustment to include junk bonds reflects a weakening US loan market, where a selloff in software debt has increased distressed loans and pushed a leveraged loan index to a two-month low. Similar shifts toward bond market funding were seen in a $1.8 billion debt package for TreeHouse Foods Inc.’s acquisition. Goldman Sachs and TJC representatives did not comment.

Arclin agreed in August to buy DuPont’s Aramids business, valued at approximately $1.8 billion. Aramids are high-strength fibers used in protective equipment such as body armor and fire-resistant clothing. The deal is projected to close in Q1 2026. Arclin last raised leveraged loans in May 2024, securing $340 million in incremental debt. DuPont has been divesting assets following a broader reorganization announced in May 2024.

Bloomberg.heading: Google Backs Up $185 Billion in AI Spending With Receipts
Bloomberg.summary:
Alphabet Inc. announced plans for capital expenditures (CapEx) in 2026 ranging between $175 billion and $185 billion, significantly exceeding the Bloomberg consensus estimate of approximately $119.5 billion. This projected spending more than doubles the anticipated increase from 2025 levels and initially caused Alphabet’s shares to drop over 7% in after-hours trading. However, after investors reviewed the company’s strong quarterly results—beating revenue, profit, YouTube ads, and cloud computing expectations—share losses were partially recovered, though they ended slightly lower.

Alphabet’s growing AI business was a key factor in offsetting investor concerns. The company is integrating its Gemini chatbot into various products such as Gmail and Chrome, adding 100 million monthly active users quarter-over-quarter, with increased user engagement reported by CEO Sundar Pichai. Google’s search business benefited from AI integration, reversing fears that AI would reduce search usage; Google Search revenue rose 17% year-over-year. Additionally, Alphabet recently secured a technical agreement with Apple to support the updated Siri voice assistant.

Google Cloud, which delivers AI services and hardware to clients, grew 48% year-over-year, establishing itself as the fastest-growing among the main cloud providers. Its investment in proprietary AI chips has reduced dependence on Nvidia hardware. The cloud backlog, indicating future sales commitments, expanded 55% year-over-year, driven by multiple customers, contrasting with Microsoft’s backlog, which is heavily weighted by OpenAI. CEO Pichai emphasized that the significant CapEx is an investment in future opportunities, reflecting strong demand across Google DeepMind and cloud services, signaling a strategic push to accelerate AI development and integration.

Bloomberg.heading: Microsoft Gets Rare Downgrade as Stifel Warns on Azure Growth
Bloomberg.summary:
Microsoft Corp. was downgraded by Stifel from buy to hold on February 4, citing overly optimistic consensus expectations for 2027. Analyst Brad Reback pointed to two main issues: slowing growth in Microsoft’s Azure cloud-computing business and significant capital expenditures on artificial intelligence (AI). He lowered his price target from $540 to $392, the lowest on Wall Street. Reback expects the stock to remain range-bound until either Azure growth accelerates significantly or capital spending growth slows below Azure’s growth.

Despite the downgrade, Microsoft remains highly favored on Wall Street, with about 96% of analysts maintaining buy-equivalent ratings and none recommending selling. The average analyst price target exceeds $600, suggesting approximately 45% upside from the recent closing price of $414.19. Shares declined 2% in premarket trading and have dropped 14% since earnings, underperforming this year.

Microsoft’s recent earnings revealed slower cloud sales growth and heavy AI-related spending, raising concerns about when the investment will yield stronger returns. Reback noted that the current AI spending is likely detrimental to operating-margin leverage and sees little chance of near-term Azure growth acceleration, citing supply challenges and competition from Alphabet’s Google Cloud Platform and Anthropic.

Microsoft is one of the top three cloud providers alongside Alphabet and Amazon, with Amazon’s results expected soon. These concerns come amid broader market caution regarding the long-term growth outlook for software companies impacted by AI. A major software-focused exchange-traded fund has dropped 15% over seven sessions and continued to decline slightly in premarket trading.

Bloomberg.heading: Nvidias Doubts About OpenAI Are a Warning for Microsoft
Bloomberg.summary:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has indicated that his previously announced $100 billion investment in OpenAI is nonbinding and may be reduced to a smaller commitment in the tens of billions amid OpenAI’s current fundraising efforts, which also involve Microsoft and Amazon seeking roughly $100 billion before a potential IPO. While Huang denies dissatisfaction with OpenAI, he has privately questioned its business discipline. OpenAI, led by CEO Sam Altman, has made aggressive but sometimes unfocused moves, including commitments for $1.4 trillion in computing resources—far exceeding projected revenues—and unsuccessful product attempts like the GPT Store.

Microsoft, holding a 27% stake in OpenAI valued at about $135 billion after an initial $13 billion investment, has exclusive access to OpenAI’s intellectual property through 2032. However, Microsoft has struggled to effectively leverage this, with its flagship AI product, Copilot, criticized for poor usability and functionality compared to competitors like Anthropic’s Claude Cowork, which offers advanced assistant capabilities across personal computing tasks. Microsoft’s internal AI development efforts to complement OpenAI have also been questioned, prompting scrutiny over its AI leadership.

OpenAI’s reluctance to fully share technical details of its models has frustrated Microsoft, although recent integration of GPT-5 has improved Copilot. The next several years will be crucial for Microsoft to better utilize its OpenAI access and improve product execution amid increasing AI commoditization. Nvidia's hesitation signals the importance of strategic execution in this competitive landscape. The original Nvidia investment plan, announced in September 2025, involved building at least 10 gigawatts of AI data-center capacity with Nvidia hardware.

Bloomberg.heading: Nvidia Partner Hon Hais Sales Soar in Sign of Strong AI Demand
Bloomberg.summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co. (Foxconn) reported a 35.5% increase in revenue for January, totaling NT$730 billion ($23 billion), indicating strong demand for Nvidia Corp. servers amid global AI development. The year-on-year comparison may have been influenced by the timing of the Lunar New Year holidays, which in 2025 occurred in January. Hon Hai is expected to report a 28% sales increase for the first quarter ending March. As a key manufacturer of servers that house chips for data centers, Hon Hai benefits from major U.S. companies, including Meta Platforms Inc. and Amazon.com Inc., investing heavily in hardware required to develop and run AI technology. This growth occurs despite concerns about potential overcapacity and uncertainty regarding the monetization of AI.

Bloomberg.heading: Elon Musk Alone Cant Explain Teslas Owner Exodus
Bloomberg.summary:
Tesla is facing challenges in 2025, with global sales declining by 9% and U.S. sales dropping 7% compared to 2024. In California, Tesla’s share of new vehicle registrations fell below 10%. While Elon Musk’s controversial behavior and public image have contributed to some customer defections, broader industry factors also impact Tesla’s performance. These include a global slowdown in electric vehicle (EV) sales growth, loss of federal tax credits, reduced emissions waivers and carbon credit revenues, concerns over battery life and rapid technological changes, as well as charging infrastructure issues.

Increased competition from established automakers and Chinese manufacturers has eroded Tesla’s market share, which fell below 50% in the U.S. in 2024. Tesla’s brand value also declined 26% in 2025 to $43 billion, with Chinese EV maker BYD surpassing it as the world’s best-selling EV manufacturer. Tesla’s lineup has aged, with no new models launched since the Cybertruck in 2023, and the Model S and Model X are set for discontinuation. Customer complaints over outdated technology, build quality, and poor service have further affected loyalty. Despite this, most former Tesla owners who switch brands choose other EVs rather than internal combustion vehicles.

Tesla is shifting focus toward robotics and artificial intelligence, with plans for the Optimus robot and potential mergers involving Musk’s other ventures, xAI and SpaceX. Brand loyalty shows signs of recovery, aided by incentives and Musk’s quieter public profile. However, Tesla faces regulatory scrutiny over its Full Self-Driving system, which remains supervised rather than fully autonomous. Industry analysts suggest Tesla’s future growth will rely on technological leadership and reduced distractions from Musk’s personal controversies.

Bloomberg.heading: Tesla Sued Over Crash That Trapped, Killed Massachusetts Driver
Bloomberg.summary:
Samuel Tremblett, 20, died after being trapped inside his burning Tesla Model Y SUV following a crash near Boston in October, according to a lawsuit filed in Massachusetts federal court. Tremblett was unable to open the vehicle’s electrically powered doors after the incident and died from thermal injuries and smoke inhalation. The lawsuit highlights ongoing concerns about Tesla’s electric door systems, which have been linked to at least 15 deaths in over a dozen incidents over the past decade where occupants or rescuers could not open doors of crashed Teslas that caught fire.

Tesla has faced multiple lawsuits alleging door-related entrapment, including a case involving a Cybertruck crash in California that resulted in three deaths. Tesla’s vehicles feature two batteries: a low-voltage battery controlling interior functions like door locks, and a high-voltage battery for propulsion. If the low-voltage battery fails, the doors may not unlock electrically and must be opened manually from inside, though many occupants are unfamiliar with these mechanical releases.

In response to safety concerns, Tesla announced plans to redesign door handles and updated its website to state that, after serious collisions, hazard lights activate and doors automatically unlock to facilitate emergency access. Regulatory bodies have also increased scrutiny of electric door handles: China banned concealed exterior handles and mandated mechanical releases, while European regulators plan stricter rules. The U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has launched probes into Tesla Model Y and Model 3 door handle malfunctions that trapped occupants.

In January, U.S. lawmakers proposed legislation requiring manual door releases and emergency access provisions in new vehicles. The Tremblett lawsuit reflects broader safety challenges linked to electric door mechanisms on Tesla vehicles. The case is Tremblett v. Tesla, 1:26-cv-10567, District of Massachusetts.

Bloomberg.heading: Watchlist - Bloomberg
Bloomberg.summary: Please provide the financial news article you would like me to summarize.

WSJ.heading: A Bullish Tech Roadmap From History
WSJ.summary:
The recent selloff in AI-related software stocks has extended to broader tech firms and semiconductor companies like AMD, Qualcomm, and Arm, amid concerns over imperfect results and weak earnings guidance. Alphabet’s shares declined despite an 18% revenue increase, with the company announcing plans to double capital expenditures on data centers and other projects. Amazon is set to report quarterly results after market close. Overall market sentiment points to a flat start, while silver and bitcoin prices continue to decline.

Analysts compare the current AI market dynamics to the 1990s internet boom, noting strong parallels in timing and investor enthusiasm. The public launch of ChatGPT in late 2022 is likened to the release of Netscape Navigator in 1994, marking a shift toward widespread AI adoption. Investor surveys suggest most believe the AI market is in its early to middle stage rather than nearing a climax, with historical comparisons indicating potential for continued growth over several years. However, concerns remain about high valuations, as the S&P 500’s Shiller P/E ratio has reached levels seen in late 1999, reflecting possible overpricing reminiscent of the tech bubble.

Recent corporate earnings reports highlight mixed results: Qualcomm’s shares dropped over 10% due to weak guidance and memory supply issues; AMD’s stock rose slightly premarket despite a recent 17% drop after disappointing earnings; Samsung Electronics shares fell nearly 6% following a significant prior gain; and Shell reported declining profits related to weaker oil-trading performance. Intercontinental Exchange faces pressure with shares down amid waning investor interest in software and financial data sectors.

Upcoming earnings reports from ConocoPhillips, Hershey, KKR, and Amazon are anticipated. The article underscores that while AI has generated substantial market value quickly, investment decisions should consider stock valuations and market fundamentals rather than solely relying on historical analogies or index levels.

WSJ.heading: Alphabet’s Cloud Is Shining as CapEx Heads Even Higher. The Stock Is Falling.
WSJ.summary:
Alphabet, Google’s parent company, reported strong fourth-quarter earnings with revenue of $113.8 billion, up 18% year-over-year and above Wall Street expectations. Earnings-per-share reached $2.82, exceeding the consensus estimate of $2.63. Google Cloud revenue rose 48% to $17.7 billion, surpassing analyst forecasts, with operating margins improving to 30.1% from 17.5% the previous year. The company plans to significantly increase capital expenditures for 2026, forecasting $175 to $185 billion, well above the prior estimate of around $115 billion, primarily to support growing demand for AI cloud computing. Depreciation expenses related to capex are expected to rise 38% in 2025 and accelerate in 2026, potentially impacting cloud operating margins.

Despite heavy investment, Google Cloud anticipates supply constraints in 2026, while its cloud backlog grew 55% to $240 billion. Advertising also performed strongly, with Search ad revenue up 17% year-over-year, beating expectations, though YouTube ad sales rose only 9%. Alphabet faces competitive pressures from AI startups like OpenAI and Anthropic, but recent AI advancements, including the Gemini 3 models and AI summaries in search, have strengthened its market position. Regulatory challenges persist, but recent legal outcomes have been less severe than feared. Alphabet’s stock has gained 81% over six months, reflecting improved market sentiment amid ongoing competition and regulatory scrutiny.

WSJ.heading: Amazon Fined in Germany Over Price-Filtering Tools
WSJ.summary: German antitrust authorities fined Amazon €59 million ($69.7 million) for using pricing tools that restrict the visibility of third-party sellers’ listings on its marketplace, ruling that these practices violate competition law. The Federal Cartel Office (FCO) stated that Amazon’s mechanisms, which filter or remove listings based on pricing, can cause significant sales losses for sellers and allow Amazon to influence competitor prices, including imposing price caps. The FCO ordered Amazon to stop using these tools in most cases but permits intervention when prices are excessively high. Amazon’s system evaluates offers based on price and other factors, promoting listings most attractive to customers. When prices are considered unusually high, listings may be downgraded or removed. Amazon maintains that sellers set their own prices independently. FCO President Andreas Mundt emphasized that legally permissible offers should not be restricted based on price alignment with Amazon’s expectations. The imposed fine reflects estimated economic benefits Amazon gained from the pricing tools and is a partial amount, as Amazon continues using them. The decision is not final; Amazon has one month to appeal before the Federal Court of Justice reviews the case. Amazon Germany’s country manager, Rocco Braeuniger, announced plans to appeal, arguing the ruling conflicts with EU competition law and uniquely forces Amazon to promote uncompetitive prices in Germany. Amazon has been under increased regulatory scrutiny since 2022, when it was designated of paramount importance for cross-border competition, triggering intensified oversight to prevent anticompetitive conduct.

WSJ.heading: Cathie Wood’s ARK Funds Buy the AMD Stock Drop
WSJ.summary:
Cathie Wood’s ARK Investment Management purchased 141,108 shares of Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) on Wednesday, valued at $28.2 million, following the chip maker’s largest one-day decline since May 2017. AMD’s shares dropped 17% to $200.19 after the company reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and revenue but provided cautious guidance, which did not meet investor expectations. Despite this, AMD stock rose slightly by 0.8% to $200.97 on Thursday, supported by forecasts from Alphabet of increased capital spending likely to benefit chip manufacturers.

In addition to AMD, ARK’s exchange-traded funds acquired shares Wednesday in several other companies, including health technology firm Tempus AI, electric vehicle manufacturer Tesla, biotech company GeneDx, cloud computing provider CoreWeave, cryptocurrency exchange Bullish, stablecoin issuer Circle Internet Group, soccer club owner Brera, and autonomous trucking company Kodiak AI.

ARK Investment Management is known for investing significantly in emerging technology sectors such as artificial intelligence, cryptocurrency, and innovative tech stocks. The ARK Innovation ETF and ARK Next Generation Internet ETF delivered strong performance in the previous year, gaining 35% and 37%, respectively, outperforming the S&P 500’s 16% gain. This marked the third consecutive year the Next Generation Internet ETF outperformed the broader market.

WSJ.heading: Berkshire Is Scoring Big With Japanese Trading Companies: 5 Stocks Worth Almost $40 Billion
WSJ.summary:
Berkshire Hathaway’s investment in five Japanese trading companies—Itochu, Marubeni, Mitsubishi, Mitsui, and Sumitomo—has grown to nearly $40 billion in 2026, following a stock rally this year. Berkshire holds about 9% stakes in each company, whose market capitalizations range from $4.6 billion (Sumitomo) to over $10 billion (Mitsubishi). In 2026, Mitsubishi and Marubeni shares have risen approximately 20%, outperforming the Topix index's 7% gain.

Berkshire’s original investment cost was $13.8 billion, initiated in 2019 and disclosed in 2020, meaning the investment has almost tripled in value. Currency effects are excluded from this figure, as Berkshire hedged yen exposure by issuing debt in Japan; through 2024, it recorded more than $2 billion in after-tax gains from the weaker yen, which depreciated about 40% against the dollar since 2020.

These companies engage in investments and trading across natural resources and infrastructure sectors. Collectively, they represent Berkshire’s third-largest equity holding after Apple and American Express. Berkshire acquired the stakes at less than ten times earnings; since then, profit growth and expanded price/earnings multiples have increased the investment’s value.

Warren Buffett highlighted in a shareholder letter that Berkshire was attracted by the companies’ undervaluation and sound financials. The companies increase dividends appropriately, buy back shares sensibly, and maintain conservative executive compensation compared to U.S. firms. Berkshire intends to hold the positions long-term and may raise ownership above 10%, though not significantly higher.

The investment contrasts with fewer successes in Berkshire’s post-Covid equity activity, which included gains in Alphabet but also losses in Occidental Petroleum and Paramount, and ill-timed sales of major bank holdings between 2020 and 2022. The Japanese trading companies exemplify Buffett’s value-investing approach and have been a notable success for Berkshire.

WSJ.heading: Why Google’s Bad News Was Good News for Broadcom and Nvidia
WSJ.summary:
Broadcom shares rose 2% following Alphabet’s announcement of a substantial increase in capital expenditure for 2024, with plans to spend $175 billion to $185 billion, up from $91 billion to $93 billion in 2025. The key focus is on AI infrastructure, including data centers and related chips. Broadcom, a partner in Google’s development of Tensor Processing Units (TPUs), is expected to benefit significantly, with these AI chips likely representing over 80% of Broadcom’s AI compute sales according to BofA Securities. Approximately 60% of Google’s capital spending will go toward short-term assets, including TPUs, although Google has not specified exact AI chip allocations.

Jefferies analyst Blayne Curtis estimates Broadcom’s potential revenue from Google’s TPU business could reach around $80 billion by 2027, projecting 6 million TPU units for Google that year, with Broadcom supplying 85% to 90%. Broadcom faces competition from Taiwan’s MediaTek, which is expected to capture 30%-40% of the TPU market in the long term, according to J.P. Morgan analyst Gokul Hariharan, who also notes no expected reduction in Broadcom’s supply chain outlook.

Nvidia shares declined 1.3%, as its GPUs and Google’s TPUs are viewed as rivals; however, Alphabet continues to offer both to cloud customers. Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai emphasized the company’s broad AI compute options, including its own TPUs and Nvidia GPUs, on a recent earnings call.

WSJ.heading: Broadcom’s stock rises on Google’s spending plans, but Nvidia’s stock extends decline
WSJ.summary: Alphabet’s Google increased its capital expenditure forecast for 2026 to a range of $175 billion to $185 billion, approximately double its spending in 2023. This move underscores the company’s continued heavy investment in artificial intelligence. Despite this announcement, semiconductor stocks have not seen a corresponding rise, as they remain affected by the broader technology sector selloff.

WSJ.heading: Estée Lauder Sank After Earnings. Better-Looking Days Are Ahead.
WSJ.summary:
Estée Lauder reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of 87 cents per share on an adjusted basis, beating expectations, but the unadjusted figure including restructuring costs was 44 cents. The company also forecasted a $100 million profit drag in fiscal 2026 due to tariffs. Following the report, Estée Lauder’s stock dropped more than 21%, marking its largest single-day percentage decline in over 30 years, and is now down 10% year-to-date, compared to a flat S&P 500.

Despite stronger-than-expected earnings, higher costs challenged investor confidence. The stock had risen about 80% over the past year but remained well below post-pandemic 2021 highs. Positive trends included accelerated organic sales growth in three of four regions and product categories, notably with mainland China sales rising 13% and becoming the top contributor to growth. The company lifted its organic sales growth forecast to 1%-3% from a prior range of flat to 3%.

Analysts noted continued progress in U.S. market stabilization, double-digit operating margins, and early benefits from new retail strategies involving Amazon, TikTok Shop, and shoppable content. While some caution that sustained momentum is needed, many expect the stock to find support near current levels as earnings expectations adjust downward. Management remains cautiously optimistic that improvements in China sales and travel retail will support recovery, signaling a gradual, ongoing turnaround.

WSJ.heading: Google Needed to Calm AI Fears.  What the Stock Market Got Instead.
WSJ.summary:
Software stocks are experiencing a severe selloff, with the broader market unsettled by conflicting impacts of artificial intelligence (AI) on various sectors, while assets like gold, silver, and Bitcoin have fallen sharply this February. Alphabet, Google's parent company, announced it plans to invest up to $185 billion in AI this year—double last year's spending and exceeding the total spent in the previous three years combined. CEO Sundar Pichai emphasized strong demand across their services, but investor concerns remain about the high AI spending without clear returns and the slow adoption of AI despite its potential to disrupt many industries.

The software sector has suffered significant losses, shedding over $1 trillion in value in the past week, with relevant ETFs dropping nearly 25% over six months. This reflects a market shift, as investors grow cautious about the AI theme and increasingly favor selectivity within technology. Meanwhile, sectors like energy, industrials, and materials are among the top performers recently, with value stocks outperforming growth stocks year-to-date.

Economic indicators offer mixed signals: some analysts argue GDP growth forecasts are too pessimistic, but labor market data shows weak private-sector hiring outside healthcare and education. Companies are investing heavily in AI but hesitant to expand payrolls amid trade uncertainties. This dynamic contributes to a "K-shaped" economy, complicating Federal Reserve policy and affecting consumer spending at lower income levels.

Market volatility has risen, with the VIX index increasing 25% in five days, suggesting larger expected daily moves for the S&P 500. Investors await upcoming data releases, including jobs reports, inflation figures, and Nvidia's earnings. Despite a solid earnings and economic outlook, the tech sector's downturn remains dominant.

WSJ.heading: Google Needed to Calm AI Fears.  What the Stock Market Got Instead.
WSJ.summary:
Software stocks are experiencing significant declines amid market uncertainty about the impact of artificial intelligence (AI). Alphabet, Google's parent company, announced plans to spend up to $185 billion on AI investments this year, doubling last year's amount and exceeding the total of the previous three years combined. Despite strong demand for its AI services, Alphabet did not provide clarity on the expected returns from these investments. This reflects a broader investor concern: major AI companies are investing heavily without clear profitability, while AI’s adoption remains limited but potentially disruptive to many industries.

Software stocks have lost over $1 trillion in value in the past week, with the iShares Expanded Tech-Software ETF down nearly 25% over six months. Market participants are increasingly selective, rotating out of growth and software stocks into value stocks tied to economic growth. Energy, industrials, and materials have been among the best performing sectors recently. The S&P 500 Value index has risen 3.9% year-to-date, whereas the Growth index has declined 1.8%.

Economic data present a mixed picture. While some analysts argue GDP growth forecasts may be conservative, labor market data show weak private sector hiring, with gains concentrated in healthcare and education. Many companies are investing in AI but are hesitant to expand headcount amid economic uncertainty. This dynamic contributes to a “K-shaped” economy, where growth and income gains are unevenly distributed, complicating Federal Reserve policy and consumer spending.

Market volatility has increased, with the VIX index rising 25% over five days and nearing 22, implying expected daily S&P 500 moves of about 1.4%. Investors await upcoming economic data, inflation reports, and major earnings updates, including Nvidia’s fourth-quarter results. Nonetheless, the ongoing tech sector selloff continues to dominate market trends.

WSJ.heading: How Apple’s stock has become a surprise winner during the $1.2 trillion tech wipeout
WSJ.summary: Apple shares have risen by 6% this week as of Thursday morning, outperforming the broader Nasdaq index, which has declined by 3% over the same period. Apple is the only company among the "Magnificent Seven" tech stocks to show gains this week. On Wednesday, Apple’s stock outperformed the Nasdaq by 4 percentage points, marking its largest one-day relative gain in more than a year, based on data from Dow Jones Market Data.

WSJ.heading: Snap Stock Gets Upgraded After Earnings. Not All of Wall Street Is So Optimistic.
WSJ.summary:
Snap Inc., the parent company of Snapchat, received an upgraded rating from B. Riley analyst Naved Khan, who raised his rating from Neutral to Buy and maintained a $10 price target following the company’s better-than-expected fourth-quarter financial results. Khan highlighted Snap’s progress in developing new revenue streams, particularly noting a 71% year-over-year increase in paid subscribers, reaching 24 million. He also emphasized the introduction of paid memory storage plans as a positive factor supporting subscription revenue growth, marking a shift from the previously free service launched in 2016. This effort aims to diversify Snap’s revenue, which is predominantly derived from advertising. Despite these positives, Snap reported a decline in daily active users for the quarter, attributed to reduced marketing expenditures as the company focuses on improving margins and profitability.

On the financial front, Snap reported $1.48 billion in fourth-quarter advertising revenue, slightly below Wall Street estimates of $1.49 billion, and provided guidance for lower first-quarter revenue than anticipated. Following the report, Snap’s shares fell 11% to $5.28.

Other analysts expressed cautious views. Canaccord Genuity’s Maria Ripps lowered her price target from $9 to $7, maintaining a Hold rating due to muted advertising revenue growth and ongoing economic uncertainties that could impact advertisers’ budgets, potentially favoring larger competitors. Similarly, Wells Fargo’s Ken Gawrelski reduced his price target to $8 from $10, maintaining an Equal-Weight rating. He noted the challenge Snap faces in competing with major players like Meta Platforms, Alphabet, and Amazon, which invest significantly in advertising performance.

Overall, despite strategic initiatives and some subscriber growth, Snap continues to face challenges in advertising revenue growth and competitive pressures in the digital ad market.

WSJ.heading: Why SpaceX Is the Loser in Its Merger With xAI
WSJ.summary:
SpaceX has acquired Elon Musk’s AI company xAI, forming an integrated innovation entity aiming to deploy AI data centers in space to overcome limitations like real estate and power. The acquisition surprised investors, positioning SpaceX as a major AI player due to its unmatched launch capabilities.

Before the deal, SpaceX was highly profitable, with estimated EBITDA margins up to 50%, compared to around 20% for aerospace firms in the S&P 500. Its Starlink satellite internet service reportedly became profitable in 2024, and its reusable rocket technology supports a near-monopoly in Western launch markets. SpaceX could potentially generate $10 billion in EBITDA by 2026. In contrast, xAI operates in a capital-intensive and competitive AI market, generating little revenue and no profits, similar to early-stage AI companies like OpenAI.

The merger increases risk for SpaceX shareholders as it integrates a loss-making AI business but provides growth potential. Elon Musk, major shareholder of both companies, appears supportive of the move.

Twitter, renamed X, was acquired by Musk for $44 billion in 2022, but investors had heavily written down their valuations by 2024. In early 2025, xAI purchased Twitter for the same price, leading to a combined entity valued at $113 billion. This transaction significantly benefited original Twitter shareholders, effectively doubling their investment, as they now hold SpaceX equity, anticipated to see a valuation increase ahead of a planned 2026 IPO.

Overall, the merger shifts value and risk dynamics across SpaceX, xAI, and former Twitter shareholders, with Musk positioning the group to capitalize on the growing AI sector alongside space technology.

WSJ.heading: How the AI Trade Went From Market Savior to Saboteur
WSJ.summary:
Investors are increasingly concerned that artificial intelligence (AI), once a key driver of the recent stock market rally, may now pose risks to tech and other sectors due to its high capital requirements and disruptive potential. The tech-heavy Nasdaq has experienced notable declines compared to the broader S&P 500, fueled by reports such as Nvidia’s delay in providing up to $100 billion in funding to OpenAI and competition from AI models like Anthropic’s Claude, which threatens companies in legal and coworking services.

Although Nvidia has denied funding issues and AI-driven productivity gains remain a central optimism driver, worries persist about the large investments needed to sustain AI innovation. For example, OpenAI has committed to spending $1 trillion, intensifying competition among major tech firms to expand AI infrastructure. Experts caution against assuming all Big Tech companies will benefit equally from AI advancements.

AI’s potential to replace extensive portions of the tech industry raises concerns that earnings losses in affected sectors may offset efficiency gains in the short to medium term. Software, constituting over 40% of the Information Technology sector, has faced a sharp downturn, with S&P 500 software stocks hitting a five-year low relative to the broader index amid fears of industry disruption, layoffs, and credit stress.

Despite these tensions, some analysts recommend viewing current market weakness in AI-related stocks as a buying opportunity, particularly in semiconductor and consumer discretionary sectors. Semiconductor equipment firms are seen as relatively protected due to ongoing demand for capacity expansion. Additionally, cyclical sectors like industrials, financials, materials, energy, and small-cap stocks might outperform amid steady economic growth.

Investors are advised to diversify, favoring sectors less vulnerable to AI disruptions. Retailers, industrial goods manufacturers, and energy producers, with core businesses tied to physical products, may provide more stable exposure. Exchange-traded funds focused on retail rather than tech-heavy consumer discretionary stocks are also suggested for balancing risk.

Overall, while AI induces uncertainty within tech, broader market resilience depends on sustained economic growth and performance in non-tech sectors.

WSJ.heading: These Stocks Are Today’s Movers: Alphabet, Qualcomm, Broadcom, AMD, Strategy, Novo Nordisk, Amazon, and More
WSJ.summary:
Stocks declined for a third consecutive day on Thursday amid a tech sector selloff following Alphabet's earnings report. Alphabet shares fell 1.3% despite beating fourth-quarter earnings and revenue estimates, due to its higher-than-expected forecast of $175 billion to $185 billion in capital expenditures for 2026, driven by investments in AI cloud computing.

Chipmakers showed mixed reactions: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) dropped 3.8%, extending losses after a 17% plunge the previous day; Broadcom gained 3%; Nvidia dipped 0.2%. These companies are poised to benefit from Alphabet’s AI spending. Qualcomm shares fell 7.5% despite surpassing earnings and revenue forecasts, as it projected lower second-quarter revenue amid memory supply shortages impacting handset demand.

Other performers included Align Technology, which surged 8.9% after beating earnings and revenue expectations and reporting a strong adjusted gross margin of 72%. Arm Holdings rose 7.8% on better-than-expected fiscal third-quarter earnings, though it forecast slower revenue growth due to seasonality. Chinese electric-vehicle maker NIO’s American depositary receipts climbed 9.9% following an upbeat fourth-quarter profit forecast.

Strategy, the largest corporate Bitcoin holder, declined 14% alongside a drop in cryptocurrency prices ahead of its earnings report. Bristol Myers Squibb increased 3.6% after posting better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and providing a positive full-year outlook despite a 15% revenue decline in its legacy drug portfolio. Cardinal Health rose 8.9% after raising its fiscal-year outlook on higher second-quarter revenue.

Hims & Hers Health fell 1.1% after announcing plans to sell a compounded version of the Wegovy weight-loss drug at a lower introductory price, prompting a 7% drop in Novo Nordisk shares as the latter warned of regulatory and legal actions regarding the unapproved product.

Estee Lauder’s shares tumbled 21%, despite meeting earnings expectations, due to concerns about tariff-related impacts on fiscal 2026 profits. Amazon shares dropped 3.8% ahead of its quarterly earnings report, with investors focused on the expected 22% revenue growth in its Amazon Web Services cloud division.

WSJ.heading: Tesla Stock Falls. Play the Odds of Musk Merging It With SpaceX.
WSJ.summary:
Prediction markets like Polymarket allow investors to bet on events such as a potential Tesla-SpaceX merger. Currently, the odds on a megamerger announcement by June 30 are 17%, meaning a 17-cent bet could yield $1 if the merger occurs. Interest in combining Elon Musk’s companies into an AI-focused conglomerate has increased recently. Tesla shareholders supported investing in xAI, leading Tesla to acquire a $2 billion stake in January. SpaceX also acquired xAI ahead of its planned midyear IPO, aiming to develop a space-based AI data center.

There are strategic overlaps: Tesla, SpaceX, and xAI all develop AI technologies, with Tesla focusing on physical AI like robo-taxis, SpaceX planning space-based computing, and xAI competing with other AI chatbots. Despite this, a SpaceX IPO seems more likely than a merger, as SpaceX has an active capital-raising plan.

So far, approximately $56,000 has been wagered on the merger prediction, a relatively small amount for financial markets. Polymarket can also reflect shifting sentiment on Tesla and other topics.

As for market performance, Tesla shares dropped 2% to $397.82 in early trading, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones declining 1% and 0.6%, respectively. The previous day saw a 3.8% fall in Tesla stock amid broader tech sector losses, including a 1.5% decline in the Nasdaq Composite and a 3.4% drop for Nvidia.

WSJ.heading: A Strategic Buying Opportunity Is Emerging for Tesla Stock
WSJ.summary: Tesla's stock declined 3.5% following its January 29 earnings report, disappointing investors and briefly entering bear market territory by dropping over 20% from its December 22, 2024, 52-week high near $500. The stock found tentative support around the $400 level, just above its 200-day simple moving average, marking its first test of this trend line since breaking above a symmetrical triangle pattern in September 2024. This $400 area has historical technical significance, first tested in November 2021 and serving as a key support and resistance level throughout subsequent price movements, including a double top formation in December 2024 and January 2025. Tesla has closed above $400 for five consecutive months, suggesting this price point may now act as a strong support. Technical analysis indicates a potential bounce back toward $500 by the end of Q1 2025, with a proposed risk management strategy involving a stop loss below $370 to optimize risk/reward. These insights come from Doug Busch, senior technical analyst at Barron’s Investor Circle.

WSJ.heading: These 10 industrial stocks look ripe as investors rotate toward the sector
WSJ.summary: As of Wednesday in 2026, the S&P 500 index rose by 0.5% year-to-date, excluding dividends. Despite this overall gain, some major components experienced significant declines. Notably, Microsoft shares fell by 14.4% year-to-date. Microsoft constitutes 5.2% of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY), which is a $706 billion fund tracking the S&P 500’s market-cap-weighted performance. Earlier in the week, precious metals and bitcoin showed pullbacks, influencing market sentiment and sector performance within the broader index.

WSJ.heading: Why Alphabet’s stock is falling despite booming cloud growth
WSJ.summary: Alphabet reported a 48% increase in cloud revenue, reflecting strong growth in that segment. Despite this, the company's stock fell by 3% on Thursday morning. The decline appears related to investor concerns over Alphabet's rapidly increasing artificial intelligence (AI) expenditures. Although many analysts view Alphabet as a notable example of AI investment leading to potential financial gains, investors remain cautious. This caution is mainly due to expectations that the company’s capital expenditures may approximately double in the current year, raising questions about the impact of these rising costs on future profitability.

WSJ.heading: Why Microsoft’s stock just lost a big fan in the wake of Alphabet’s earnings
WSJ.summary: Following Alphabet’s recent earnings report highlighting strong growth in its cloud division, analyst Brad Reback of Stifel downgraded Microsoft’s stock rating from buy to hold. Reback cited the absence of near-term catalysts that might drive Microsoft’s share price higher, reflecting a more cautious outlook despite the competitive cloud market dynamics underscored by Alphabet’s performance.

Reuters.heading: Anthropic releases AI upgrade as market punishes software stocks
Reuters.summary:
Anthropic, a San Francisco-based AI startup backed by Amazon and Alphabet's Google, has launched Claude Opus 4.6, an upgraded version of its AI model released in November. The new model offers enhanced reliability and longer task handling, with improvements in coding and finance capabilities. Anthropic highlighted the model’s ability to process up to 1 million data tokens in a single prompt, matching previous claims by Google and earlier Claude versions. The company also previewed features in Claude Code, demonstrating task delegation among multiple autonomous agents to increase efficiency.

As a software industry disruptor, Anthropic aims to maintain technological leadership ahead of its planned initial public offering (IPO) amid competition from Google and OpenAI. The startup’s AI tools are gaining traction among software developers, particularly for coding, and it is seeking business deals with products like Claude Cowork, designed to assist white-collar workers in automating computer tasks.

The rapid advancement of AI technologies, including Anthropic’s, has contributed to declines in shares of traditional software companies such as Salesforce, Workday, and Thomson Reuters, which fell about 3% recently. Some industry leaders, including Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, argue that established software companies retain competitive advantages due to their specialized products, extensive data, and AI integration efforts.

Anthropic’s head of product for enterprise, Scott White, emphasized the company’s objective to integrate AI with legacy software to enhance their utility rather than replace them, describing Claude Cowork as a "front door" to improving productivity.

Reuters.heading: Bayer says its experimental blood thinner cuts risk of stroke recurrence by 26%
Reuters.summary: Bayer announced positive late-stage trial results for its experimental blood thinner, asundexian, which reduced the risk of stroke recurrence by 26% when combined with standard antiplatelet therapy, compared to antiplatelet therapy alone. The Phase III Oceanic-Stroke study involved over 12,000 patients who had previously experienced a stroke or similar cerebrovascular blockage. The trial also showed reassuring safety data regarding bleeding risks. Bayer plans to pursue regulatory approval for asundexian. The news supports CEO Bill Anderson's efforts to revamp the company amid previous financial and legal challenges, including ongoing litigation related to its Roundup weedkiller. Bayer’s stock had started to recover following the announcement of successful preliminary trial data in November and the U.S. Supreme Court agreeing to hear the company’s appeal on Roundup-related cases. The asundexian trial success comes after a previous trial at the end of 2023 failed in a larger group of patients at risk of stroke but without prior stroke events. Competitors Novartis and Bristol Myers Squibb, working with Johnson & Johnson, have not yet reported late-stage stroke prevention trial results for their similar anticoagulant drugs, abelacimab and milvexian, respectively.

Reuters.heading: Chevron names new heads of strategy, trading, business development
Reuters.summary: Chevron Corp announced senior leadership changes set to take effect in 2026, with multiple long-serving executives retiring and internal successors appointed. Frank Mount, president of corporate business development, will retire in November after 33 years, with Jake Spiering, current director of investor relations, taking over on August 1. Jeanine Wai will become director of investor relations starting April 1. Patricia Leigh, president of supply and trading, will retire in July after 35 years, succeeded by Molly Laegeler, currently chief strategy officer, effective March 1. Kevin Lyon, leading the integration of Hess assets, will take over as chief strategy officer on March 1, replacing Laegeler. Bruce Niemeyer, president of shale and tight, will retire in October after 26 years, with Gerbert Schoonman succeeding him from April 1; Niemeyer will stay on as senior executive advisor through October. These changes occur as Chevron continues integrating Hess and managing market volatility, capital discipline, and investor demands.

Reuters.heading: Cigna beats quarterly estimates, provides muted outlook
Reuters.summary: Cigna reported fourth-quarter profit and revenue that exceeded expectations, driven by strong performance in its health services unit, with shares rising 3% in early trading. However, the company issued a cautious outlook for 2026, forecasting adjusted profit per share of at least $30.25 and revenue around $280 billion, both below analyst estimates. Cigna’s business strategy includes reducing its presence in the Affordable Care Act marketplace and exiting Medicare Advantage plans, focusing instead on its pharmacy benefits segment and employer-sponsored healthcare plans. Revenue at Evernorth, Cigna’s pharmacy benefits unit, grew 20% to $36.3 billion in the quarter. The medical loss ratio increased to 88%, slightly above expectations, largely due to individual and family plans. Cigna’s CFO noted that projections reflect prudence amid ongoing elevated costs. The company reported quarterly adjusted earnings per share of $8.08, surpassing forecasts of $7.88. Additionally, Cigna settled a U.S. Federal Trade Commission insulin pricing case, agreeing to initiatives to reduce costs for patients and insurers, with no impact expected on its 2027 outlook.

Reuters.heading: Coca-Cola to discontinue frozen products in US and Canada
Reuters.summary: Coca-Cola announced it will discontinue its frozen products, including the Minute Maid frozen line, in the U.S. and Canada by the first quarter of 2026, citing shifting consumer preferences. The decision reflects the company's focus on expanding product lines that align with current demand, such as zero-sugar beverages and premium products like Fairlife milk. A company spokesperson noted the juice category is growing strongly, prompting a strategic realignment. Coca-Cola also faces a challenging regulatory environment for packaged foods in the U.S. and is introducing a cane sugar version of its flagship soda in glass bottles. The company has experienced declining sales of its classic Coke due to rising consumer preference for low-calorie drinks and increased demand for local products in markets like India and China. Henrique Braun, appointed CEO in December, is leading the company through these changes.

Reuters.heading: ConocoPhillips targets $1 billion cost cuts in 2026; profit misses on weaker oil prices
Reuters.summary:
ConocoPhillips announced plans to reduce capital and operating costs by $1 billion in 2026 following a fourth-quarter profit miss due to weaker crude prices. The company's adjusted earnings were $1.02 per share for the quarter ended December 31, below the analysts' estimate of $1.11. The average realized price of oil equivalent dropped 19% to $42.46 per barrel, partially offset by a 6.3% increase in production to 2.32 million barrels of oil equivalent per day (boepd). The company projects 2026 production between 2.33 million and 2.36 million boepd. 

CEO Ryan Lance said the cost-cutting initiative follows over $1 billion in synergies expected in 2025 from the $22.5 billion acquisition of Marathon Oil. ConocoPhillips has completed $3.2 billion in asset sales in 2025 and aims to reach a $5 billion disposition target by the end of 2026 as it streamlines operations. The company reported workforce reductions of 20-25% as part of restructuring efforts.

Unlike larger integrated peers Exxon Mobil and Chevron, which exceeded profit estimates due to refining operations, ConocoPhillips' upstream-focused business leaves it more exposed to oil price fluctuations. Shares declined 3% in afternoon trading.

Separately, ConocoPhillips is pursuing recovery of funds related to legal judgments in Venezuela and is engaging with the U.S. government on policy developments in that country. The company, once a partner of Venezuela’s PDVSA, exited its positions following nationalization between 2004 and 2007 and subsequent arbitration proceedings. Benchmark Brent crude prices averaged $63.13 per barrel in Q4, down 11.3% from the previous year amid oversupply and tariff concerns.

Reuters.heading: CVS Health to drop Amgen and Lilly's bone disease treatments from some drug lists
Reuters.summary: On February 5, CVS Health announced it will replace Amgen's Prolia and Eli Lilly's Forteo bone disease treatments with lower-cost biosimilar and generic alternatives on some preferred drug lists starting April 1. Its pharmacy benefit manager, Caremark, will add biosimilars such as CVS unit Cordavis's Ospomyv and Celltrion's Stoboclo for Prolia, as well as generic versions of Forteo like Bonsity and Tymlos, to major national commercial formularies. CVS stated this change will reduce prescription costs by over 50% compared to branded drugs. To date, CVS's biosimilar formulary strategy has generated $1.5 billion in gross savings for customers and members. Key U.S. patents for Prolia expired in 2025, and those for Forteo ended in 2019. Amgen reported global Prolia sales of approximately $1.05 billion in 2025. This move follows Caremark’s earlier decision in 2024 to exclude AbbVie’s Humira in favor of cheaper biosimilars, with about 96% of Humira users switching to biosimilars. Biosimilars differ from conventional generics as they are complex biotech drugs derived from living cells and are not exact copies. Pharmacy benefit managers like Caremark negotiate drug pricing and create insurance-covered medication lists. CVS Caremark, Cigna's Express Scripts, and UnitedHealth’s Optum Rx together control 80% of the U.S. prescription drug market.

Reuters.heading: German cartel office bans Amazon from using price controls
Reuters.summary: Germany's Federal Cartel Office has banned Amazon from imposing price caps on third-party sellers in its German online marketplace. For the first time, the regulator is also demanding Amazon return several million euros, initially set at 59 million euros ($69.54 million), citing anti-competitive behavior. The cartel office stated that Amazon, which competes directly with other marketplace retailers, cannot influence competitors' prices except in rare cases such as preventing price gouging. This action utilizes new regulatory powers granted through reforms in 2023. Amazon's Germany chief, Rocco Braeuniger, announced the company will appeal the decision, describing it as unprecedented and indicating that the company will continue operations normally. Braeuniger also warned that forcing Amazon to allow uncompetitive or abusive pricing could harm the shopping experience. Separately, Germany is investigating whether Chinese e-commerce platform Temu is influencing third-party sellers' prices. The decision allows Amazon one month to appeal.

Reuters.heading: Germany to require streaming platforms to invest in local production
Reuters.summary: Germany plans to implement new investment requirements for streaming platforms and TV broadcasters, mandating that they reinvest at least 8% of their annual revenue earned in the country into the local film industry. If these companies choose to invest 12% or more, they will be exempt from certain regulations, such as producing films in the German language. This initiative aims to strengthen Germany's position as a film-making hub amid challenges like rising labor, energy, and materials costs affecting the sector. The government will also nearly double annual funding for domestic film production to 250 million euros ($295.2 million). Germany joins several European countries, including France and Italy, that require streaming services to contribute to local production. The legislation is expected to be approved by the cabinet before early April, though enforcement measures for non-compliance have not yet been specified. The announcement was made ahead of the Berlin Film Festival and underlines a focus on supporting jobs, value creation, and creative development within the industry.

Reuters.heading: Rival bidders pursue Lukoil assets despite Carlyle deal, sources say
Reuters.summary:
At least two companies, including Chevron in partnership with Quantum Energy Partners, and a group led by investment bank Xtellus Partners, remain in talks with Russian energy company Lukoil and the U.S. government regarding the sale of Lukoil’s global assets. This follows Lukoil’s initial agreement to sell the portfolio to U.S. private equity firm Carlyle announced on January 29. Carlyle’s purchase excludes Lukoil’s Kazakhstan assets and involves potential partnerships with Abu Dhabi-based funds Mubadala, XRG, and IHC, as well as the U.S. Development Finance Corporation. The deal requires approval from the U.S. Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), the Kremlin, and the Russian central bank.

The asset portfolio, initially valued at approximately $22 billion, has attracted interest from multiple parties, including ExxonMobil and Bernd Bergmair, the former owner of Pornhub. The U.S. Treasury previously rejected bids from Geneva-based commodity trader Gunvor and Xtellus. Xtellus, formerly the U.S. branch of Russian bank VTB, is collaborating with American billionaire Todd Boehly and UAE’s Allied Investment Partners. Their consortium proposed a payment method involving frozen Lukoil shares owned by U.S. investors instead of cash, and discussions with U.S. officials are ongoing.

Lukoil faces a February 28 deadline set by the U.S. Treasury to complete the sale, a move linked to sanctions imposed last year on Lukoil and Rosneft aimed at pressuring Moscow over the Ukraine conflict. The transaction’s status remains uncertain, with sources indicating negotiations with multiple potential buyers continue. Chevron and Quantum declined to comment, while Carlyle is conducting due diligence on the assets.

Reuters.heading: Snowstorms boost US weekly jobless claims; job openings hit more than five-year low
Reuters.summary:
Last week, initial U.S. unemployment claims rose by 22,000 to 231,000, exceeding economists' expectations and marking the largest increase since early December. This rise was attributed primarily to severe winter weather affecting states like Pennsylvania, New York, and New Jersey, as well as seasonal volatility. The four-week moving average of claims increased slightly to 212,250. Continuing claims, representing individuals receiving ongoing unemployment benefits, also rose by 25,000 to 1.844 million after three weeks of decline. Despite these fluctuations, layoffs remained low in December.  

Separately, the Labor Department's Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey (JOLTS) reported a decrease in job openings to 6.542 million in December, the lowest since September 2020 and below forecasts. The decline of 386,000 vacancies was mainly concentrated in the professional and business services sector, which saw a drop of 257,000 openings. Other sectors, including retail, financial activities, healthcare, and arts and entertainment, also experienced fewer openings. The job openings rate fell to 3.9% from 4.2% in November.  

Hiring increased modestly by 172,000 to 5.293 million, supported by healthcare and accommodation and food services sectors, while hiring slowed in professional and business services. The hires rate rose slightly to 3.3%. The quits rate, indicative of worker confidence, remained steady at 2.0%, though resignation patterns varied by sector. The layoffs rate held steady at 1.1%.  

Economists noted the labor market shows signs of stability with judicious hiring amid uncertainty stemming from import tariffs and increasing use of artificial intelligence, which may be causing some businesses to delay hiring. The data precede the delayed January employment report expected to show a modest jobs increase around 70,000. Market reactions included lower stock prices, a stronger dollar, and falling Treasury yields. The Federal Reserve maintained its interest rates at 3.50%-3.75%, with expectations to hold steady for the first half of 2024 given current labor market conditions.

Reuters.heading: Spotify to let users buy physical books on app through Bookshop.org partnership
Reuters.summary:
Spotify announced a partnership with online retailer Bookshop.org to start selling physical books on its streaming platform, expanding beyond its existing audiobooks business. This new feature will roll out in the U.S. and UK later this spring, with Bookshop.org managing pricing, inventory, and fulfillment. Spotify will earn an affiliate fee on purchases made through its app.

Since launching audiobooks two years ago, Spotify's Premium Audiobooks service has expanded to 22 markets globally, with an English catalog exceeding 500,000 titles. The service reported a 36% increase in new listeners and a 37% rise in listening hours year-over-year.

The move to sell physical books comes amid declining physical book sales industry-wide, as consumers shift to e-books and digital content. Industry reports indicate slowing book orders and closures among traditional distributors.

Spotify is also introducing "Page Match," a tool allowing users to scan a page from physical or digital books in the app to navigate to the corresponding point in an audiobook. This feature will launch on most English titles and fully roll out by February 23.

Additionally, Spotify raised its monthly Premium subscription price by $1 to $12.99 in the U.S., Estonia, and Latvia. Following the announcement, Spotify's shares dropped 4.5%, after gaining nearly 30% in the previous year.

Reuters.heading: UPS, Amazon boost US planned layoffs in January, Challenger survey shows
Reuters.summary: In January, U.S. employers announced planned layoffs totaling 108,435, a 205% increase from the previous month and the highest for any January since 2009, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. This figure was also 118% higher compared with January 2025, reflecting employers' cautious outlook for 2026. The transportation sector led the increase with 31,243 planned cuts, largely driven by United Parcel Service’s (UPS) decision to cut up to 30,000 jobs and close 24 facilities as part of its shift away from Amazon deliveries toward more profitable operations. The technology sector followed, announcing 22,291 layoffs, predominantly from Amazon’s plan to reduce its corporate workforce by 16,000. Despite these large-scale layoffs, they are not expected to significantly affect weekly unemployment claims. The healthcare sector also faced notable cuts, partly due to lower federal Medicaid and Medicare reimbursements. The main reasons cited for layoffs were loss of contracts and unfavorable market and economic conditions, with restructuring and closures also contributing. Artificial intelligence was cited as a factor in 7% of layoffs, though its specific impact remains unclear. Hiring intentions were weak, with only 5,306 announced for January, the lowest since 2009, primarily within the insurance industry.

Reuters.heading: US software shares sink further on mounting fears over AI disruption
Reuters.summary:
Shares of U.S. software and data services companies declined for a seventh consecutive session, driven by investor concerns that rapidly advancing artificial intelligence (AI) technologies could disrupt the sector. The S&P 500 software and services index dropped 3.1%, potentially erasing around $1 trillion in market value since January 28. Major tech firms including ServiceNow, Salesforce, and Microsoft saw significant losses of 6%, 5%, and 3%, respectively. Thomson Reuters experienced a 9% decline despite reporting Q4 results in line with estimates and raising its dividend, as investors worried about AI competition impacting its legal business.

Market analysts noted that uncertainty over AI's long-term effects has deterred dip-buyers and increased bearish sentiment, pushing the software index roughly 20% below its 200-day moving average—the deepest such decline since June 2022. The sector selloff coincides with a broader shift from technology stocks to value sectors like consumer staples, energy, and industrials.

Short interest in mid- to large-cap software firms has risen substantially over three months, particularly in cybersecurity and SaaS companies. Hedge funds have reduced exposure to software, although remain net long, reflecting a rotation from tech-driven growth to traditional sectors. This trend also affected related sectors, including asset managers like Blue Owl, which disclosed 8% exposure to software assets.

Internationally, tech stock performances were mixed: London Stock Exchange Group, RELX, and Wolters Kluwer gained, while India’s software exporters index slipped 0.7% following a sharp drop the previous day. Alphabet’s plan to nearly double capital expenditures intensified investor concerns regarding AI investment payoffs.

Overall market volatility increased, with the Cboe Volatility Index briefly hitting a two-month high above 23 before settling near 20.5. Commodities and digital assets also fell, including gold, silver, and bitcoin, which dropped below $70,000. Analysts described the situation as a market reset amid widespread adjustments of investment positions.

Reuters.heading: Wall Street tumbles as AI worries weigh
Reuters.summary:
On February 5, U.S. stock markets declined, with the Nasdaq falling to its lowest level since November. Major technology companies experienced significant losses after Alphabet announced plans to nearly double its capital expenditure on artificial intelligence (AI) to as much as $185 billion by 2026. Collectively, Big Tech firms are expected to spend over $500 billion on AI in 2024. Following this, Alphabet’s shares fell 4.2%, Microsoft dropped 3.2%, Palantir lost 6%, Oracle declined 5.6%, and Amazon slid 4% ahead of its quarterly earnings report. Nvidia, a key beneficiary of AI spending, remained nearly flat.

Investor concerns have grown over heavy AI investment as returns in revenue and profits remain uncertain. Additionally, rapidly advancing AI technologies have raised fears of reduced demand and margin pressure in traditional software sectors. Software and data services stocks continued their decline, with ServiceNow down 5.5% and Salesforce down 4.8%. The S&P 500 software index fell 3.2%, marking its seventh consecutive losing session.

Qualcomm shares dropped 7.2% after issuing revenue and profit forecasts below expectations. The CBOE volatility index briefly reached a two-month high, reflecting increased market uncertainty. Investors shifted away from expensive AI stocks towards relatively cheaper value stocks, although the S&P 500 value index still declined 1% for the day but remained positive for the week, while the growth index was down over 4% for the week.

The broader S&P 500 index fell 0.96% to 6,816.32 points, the Nasdaq declined 1.12% to 22,648.66 points, and the Dow Jones dropped 0.95% to 49,029.78 points. Sector performance was broadly negative, with materials and consumer discretionary down 2.69% and 2.25%, respectively. 

In company-specific moves, Snap missed expectations despite topping revenue estimates, leading to an almost 10% stock drop. Estee Lauder shares fell 20% after lowering its full-year outlook. Conversely, Tapestry rose 10% after raising its profit forecast, and Hershey gained 8.8% on strong annual results.

Labor market data showed a larger-than-expected increase in initial unemployment claims and a decline in job openings to the lowest in over five years as of December. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing ones by a ratio of 2.1 to 1 on the S&P 500. The index recorded 44 new highs and 9 new lows; the Nasdaq had 103 new highs but 365 new lows.
